228. McMillan, (Mrs. William)
WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. McMillan
Address: Box 8, Lumsden, Sask.
Birthplace: Hastings, County of Victoria

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1907
Where did you set up housekeeping? Box 22, 29, 10
Where had you been living before that? Windsor, Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? 8 to 10
How far was it to your nearest store? 55 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every two weeks
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Sugar, flour, apples, potatoes, beans, flour, sugar, flour, raisins

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Homestead
In what quantities did you buy it? 6 to 7 hundred
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.00 to $2.75
How much did you use graham flour? 200 to 300
Whole wheat flour? 100 to 200
Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 1 mile
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00 to $1.20
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal
Cornmeal? Yes, Whole wheat? Yes, Farina? Yes
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? In the ground...
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 lbs.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $5.00
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edward's
What size or size of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lbs.
At what price? $7.50 for 10 lbs.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Milk house.
Butter? Edward's
Eggs? Johnson's
What was the price of butter? $2.00
Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes
Did you make butter? Yes
What kind of cheese? Wisconsin White Cheddar

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork, cured.
How did you get fresh meat? Rabbit, mutton, chicken.
How often did you get fresh meat?
How did you preserve meat? Boiled, dry salt.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes
If so what year was it organized? About 1925
Did you use game? Yes
What kinds? Wild ducks
For how long? All season
What part did fish play in the family diet? Practically none
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh
Kinds?
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Darley's Blue Ribbon
At what price? $0.50
What kind of coffee did you buy? (Beans or ground) Darley's
Price? $0.50
What other beverages were used? Water

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
$1.00
Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes
If not, where from? Two green teams
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes yes Cabbage yes Carrots yes Onions yes
Turnips yes Beets yes
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 25 lbs
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box
What weight? 25 lbs How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? 40
What was the price of prunes? $0.50
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)? yes

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes
peas? yes corn? yes beans? yes Saskatoons? yes
other foods? yes
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1923
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1923
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1923
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes
To what extent? Necessary today for the year
Did you make your own vinegar? No

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ...............

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...........................................

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Both bought & made.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes... wood ash? No...

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Regular... Sunlight...

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal... Oil...

Where did you get your fuel? Lumber yard... Mine...

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. First coal was got in 1909. Now we have coal, wood, oil, propane gas, electricity.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Yes... No...

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No...

By whom was your first cook stove made? Mr. Clark...

That year was it purchased? 1887... Price? $25.00...

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron... Copper... Tin...

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) China...

When did you first see enamel ware? Before 1900...

Aluminum? 1915...
13. **SPARES**
   - Did you buy January issues or make your own? Yes
   - If so, how many? 200
   - If you rent your own, did you make any? No
   - What kind of laundry soap did the grocer recommend? Not sure

14. **FIRE**
   - What fuel did you use in the winter? Coal
   - Did you use an outdoor fireplace or open hearth in the coldest days? Yes
   - Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? No
   - By how much did your fuel costs save money? Not enough
   - Short year was it purchased? 1907
   - For preserving food? (chili, jam, etc.) Not sure
   - When did you first use aluminum? 1965
16. Wrapping and Containers

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Used the common brown paper first. Celophane is used a great deal. Meat is wrapped in oil paper in cloths. Fruits, vegetables are put in containers. Also wax paper is used a great deal.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge toast eggs syrup tea
Dinner: Potatoes carrots ham hocks pickled pork
Supper: Bread butter pudding sometimes buttermilk tea

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Chicken roasted potatoes Vegetables salad bread tea
Parents from 60 to 75 family from 16 to 31 years age

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Yes, pork & potatoes being the main meal
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, supper) for the earliest
year you can remember. Give the year and list the members at the head
of their ages at the time. State the approximate month, etc., winter
or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge and eggs. Tea

Supper: Potatoes, cold baked pork, pudding, fruit

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in another family
appreciation to those at that time.

Christmas dinner: Potatoes, vegetables, roast beef, salad, bread or brownies, dessert, pudding, tea. Cost per person $1.50.

19. Are you ever obliged to almost starve? Have you ever been forced
to locally purchased foods? Give details.

Pork & potatoes. Bring the main meal
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

More home canned meats & Vegetables/Fruit today

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

When the town's butchery started in 1908 we could purchase anything we required. My husband starting homesteading here on Sec 14, T9, R10, in 1905 so had lots of the early settler experiences.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Trading among neighbors, meat etc. During the early homesteading days my husband walked 20 miles to a store at the river for salt pork, flour & syrup. In three days we would drive 20 mi to a store and have a real good time, get home at 5 o'clock & be contented for a couple weeks. One grand thing there was never any liquor at these gatherings, I feel more free...
21. When did you begin to raise, or purchase, fruits and vegetables? Instead of buying them in town, how did you get them? (Give as many details as possible.)

When the Town Bullard started in 1908 we

emailed President Andrew Johnson.

The first fruit started growing in 1905.

So I had lots of the early settler experiences.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and everyday foods in those early pioneer days in Western Canada.

Include facts not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, problems of storage, shortages, and other details. (Use back of paper if more space is needed.)

Trading among neighbors mostly.

During the early homesteading days my husband walked 20 miles to a store at the train station, Sally Port. From there he would drive 20 miles to a town. And then a neighbor would come to town at 5 o'clock to be entertained by a couple of weeks' trip.

Grandfather there was never any crops at these places.
Oxford
